sn15.20:2.3: For Vepulla, see SN 15.10:2.2. | A pācīnavaṁsa was a hall or shed built for the ritual, with bamboo (vaṁsa) beams running easterly (pācīna; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.1.1.6 and Eggeling’s note). Perhaps the mountain was noted as the site for the introduction of this ritual institution. In the Buddha’s day, there was a “Park of the East-Raftered Hall” in Cetī (MN 128:8.1, AN 8.30:1.2).
sn15.20:2.4: Tivara may be connected to Vedic trivarūtha, the “triple defence”. This may be connected with the fortifications for which Rājagaha is famous. But by Vedic times it acquired a religious sense, here suggesting the people who have the protection of the gods due to their correct performance of the ritual in their hall. The “triple defence” can be seen as a precursor of the Buddhist triple refuge.
sn15.20:2.5: For the long lifespans of humans in the past, see AN 7.74:9.1. Declining lifespans are charted at DN 26:14.2.
sn15.20:2.7: Kakusandha and the other Buddhas are mentioned at SN 12.7–10. His lifespan of 40,000 years is confirmed at DN 14:1.7.4.
sn15.20:2.8: The pairs of disciples are listed at DN 14:1.9.1. A story of Sañjīva is given at MN 50:9.2.
sn15.20:3.2: These two terms are found in Rig Veda 4.6.9, “red horses going straight, going well” (rohitāsa ṛjvañcaḥ svañcaḥ), where rohitassa is the “red horse” of the sunbeams (SN 2.26), and Sanskrit vañca is evidently found in Pali vaṅka in the sense “going” (unless it is from vañcati, “fire”). Perhaps the mountain was named for the flashing beams of sunlight that broke over it at dawn.
sn15.20:4.1: Supassa is “Fairslope”, a name used for several mountains, including one on the eastern side of mount Meru.
sn15.20:4.5: Stories of Kassapa, the Buddha immediately preceding Gotama, are found at MN 81 and AN 5.180.His lifespan is given at DN 14:1.7.6,
sn15.20:5.5: Kauṭilya says there are fifteen muhuttas (Sanskrit muhūrta) per day, and fifteen per night, making 48 minutes (Arthaśāstra 2.20.37).
